distributionNotes: E Australia from NE Queensland through W New South Wales and Victoria, including King I and Tasmania. Distribution is primarily continuous within some catchments but dicontinuous or poorly known in others. Extinct in the Adelaide Hills and Mount Lofty Ranges in South Australia and may be extinct in various catchments throughout the rest of their distribution (Hawke et al. 2019). Introduced to E Kangaroo I.

Continental Australia, including Tasmania, Groote Eylandt, and Bigge, Mua (Hitchcock et al. 2014), Dunk, Magnetic, Fraser, North Stradbroke, King, Flinders, and Kangaroo Is; coastal and highland regions of SE and E New Guinea (including Markham Valley), both C and S Papua New Guinea and SE Papua Province, Indonesia.
Known from a single specimen and recent camera trap images and videos from Berg Rara Mt in the Cyclops Mts, extreme N Papua Province, Indonesia on New Guinea.

Highlands of New Guinea, including the Central Range from the Paniai Lakes of C Papua Province, Indonesia to the SE peninsula of Papua New Guinea (including an isolated population in the Nanneau Mts, Oro Province), the Mts of the Huon Peninsula of Morobe Province, and the Foja Mts of Papua Province, extending to lower elevations on the S side of the Central Range.
The Vogelkop Peninsula of Papua Province, Indonesia on New Guinea, including Salawati I (where it is possibly extinct) and possibly Batanta and Waigeo Is (Helgen 2007).
Andes of W Ecuador and NW Peru, S to San Andres de Cutervo, Cajamarca.
Known only from the type locality in the Cordillera del Condor, Provincia Morona-Santiago, SE Ecuador, but likely extends into Peru in the same cordillera.
Andes of WC Colombia and NW Ecuador.
Andes Cordilleras Centrales, Orientales, and C Occidentalis of Colombia and extreme SW Venezuela and the Andes of C and N Ecuador.
Five localities on the E side of the Andes of S Ecuador in Provincia Morona-Santiago (Tinguichaca, Zuñac, and Atillo) and Provincia Zamora-Chinchipe (Sabanilla and Tapichalaca).
Andes of S Peru (from Ocabamba to Llamachaqui) and NW Bolivia (La Paz Department).
SC Chile (S Los Rios and Los Lagos Regions), including Chiloé I, and WC Argentina (Puerto Blest, Provincia de Río Negro).
Veracruz, Mexico in the N, through most of Central America (excluding El Salvador) and into NW South America, including W Colombia and W Ecuador.
From N Colombia and N Venezuela to N and E Bolivia, E Paraguay, and W and S Brazil, including E Ecuador and E Peru, E of the Andes.
E South America, throughout Venezuela, the Guianan Shield, and Trinidad I, S through much of Brazil into the Atlantic Forest region.
Known from nine confirmed localities from Amazonian extreme S Colombia (Amazonas), E Peru (Loreto, Cusco, Madre de Dios), and WC and C Brazil (Rondônia, Mato Grosso).

Tropical Central and South America from S Mexico (Oaxaca, Tabasco, Chiapas) through much of Central America (other than W Guatamala and El Salvador), Colombia, Venezuela, the Guianan Shelf, Ecuador, Peru, N Bolivia, N, W, and SE Brazil, NE Argentina, and SE Paraguay. Not recorded throughout much of the Amazon Basin, although it is uncertain whether this is a true distribution gap or a sampling bias.
E Brazil.
E to SE Brazil, E Paraguay, and NE Argentina.
Guianan Shield of S and E Venezuela, NC Brazil, N Guyana, N Suriname, and NW French Guiana.

E and S Mexico (from Tamaulipas to Chiapas and the Yucatan Peninsula), S through Central America and N South America, including Colombia, Venezuela, the Guianan Shield, Ecuador, Peru, N and C Bolivia, and N and WC Brazil.
Andes of NW Venezuela, NC and W Colombia, C Ecuador, W and SC Peru, and WC Bolivia.
S Brazil, E Bolivia, Paraguay, Uruguay, and N and C Argentina.

SE Canada (SE Ontario and S Quebec) through E and C United States (with isolated populations as far W as Arizona, New Mexico, and Colorado, although it is uncertain if these are native or introduced), Mexico, and Central America S to Costa Rica. Introduced to the W United States (California, Oregon, Washington, and WC Idaho) and SW Canada (SW British Columbia) during the Great Depression.
From scattered localities throughout South America, including EC Colombia, E Venezuela, N Guyana, W Suirname, C and E Bolivia, NE Argentina, SE Brazil, E Paraguay, and Uruguay.
Restricted to the Yungas region of the Andes in NW Argentina and SC Bolivia.
NW Amazon Basin of S Venezuela, S Colombia, E Ecuador, NE and E Peru, and NW Brazil.
Scattered localities throughout C and W Brazil, N Argentina, Paraguay, E Bolivia, E Peru, NE Colombia, and Venezuela.
Found only in the Orinoco River delta region of NE Venezuela.
Amazon of WC Brazil and W Peru.
Known from Panama, Colombia, and W Ecuador, although populations from Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica may represent either this species or _P. vossi_.
Known from the E Andean foothills of S Peru (Ayacucho and Junín Departments).
The Guianan Shield (Guyana, Surinane, French Guiana) and E Amazonian Brazil (Amapá, Pará, Roraima, and part of Amazonas).
Known from E Ecaudor, E Peru, and W Amazonian Brazil.
Known from SE Brazil, NW Argentina (Misiones), and E Paraguay.

Confirmed from E and S Mexico (from Tamaulipas through Oaxaca and the Isthmus of Tehuantepec to Chiapas and the Yucatan Peninsula), Belize, and El Salvador, but may include populations from Guatemala, Nicaragua, Honduras, and Costa Rica, which may also be _P. melanurus_.
Found across Panama.
Endemic to the C highlands of C Costa Rica.
Known only from a few localities in S Peru (Cusco and Pasco).
Known only from the type locality in the upper Río Montecristo basin of Parque Nacional del Río Abiseo, San Martín Department, Peru.
Andean foothills of E Peru and E Bolivia, E across Amazonia and the Cerrado to C Brazil.
E Venezuela, the Guaianas and N and E Brazil (S to Bahia along the Atlantic coast).
Known from scattered localities in SE Colombia, E Ecuador, and NE Peru.
Found in Panama, W Colombia, and W Ecuador.
Known from the Amazonian lowlands of SE Colombia (Putumayo), E Ecuador, and NE Peru (Loreto).
Found throughout Amazonia from the Guianas, S Venezuela, and Colombia through N and W Brazil, E Ecuador, E Peru, and N Bolivia.
Found in the Amazon of Peru, Brazil and Bolivia, S of the Amazon River and West of the Tapajós River.
Found from NE Mexico (Tamaulipas) through Central America, S to E Panama.
Currently known from NW Venezuela and E Colombia E and S throughout the Guianas and Brazil (S to the the Atlantic Forest and Cerrado), as well as Tobago.
Currently known from three localities in the coastal lowlands of E Nicaragua and E Costa Rica.
Found in the Atlantic Forest of SE Brazil E and S to NE Argentina (Misiones) and E Paraguay.
Known from a few localities on the E Andean slopes of C Peru.
West Andean foothills and lowlands of SW Ecuador and NW Peru.

From the Andean foohills of C Colombia (Cauca, Huila, and Nariño); specimens that potentially represent this species are known from Ecuador, Brazil, Peru, and Venezuela, although futher research is needed to confirm the taxonomic identity of these specimens.
E slopes of the Andes in SE Peru, Bolivia, and NW Argetina, and from lowlands of E Bolivia, Paraguay, and SW Brazil.
Panama, Colombia, N Venezuela, and the islands of Isla Margarita, Trinidad, Tobago, and Grenada.
Known from a few localities in the Amazonian lowlands of SE Colombia, E Ecuador, and E Peru.
Lowlands of SE Colombia, E Ecuador, E Peru, and W Brazil.
Pacific lowlands and Andean foothills of W Ecuador and NW Peru.
Known from a few localities in the Guiana highlands of S Venezuela.
Andean lowlands of SE Colombia, E Ecuador, NE Peru, and scattered localities in the Andes of N Colombia and W Venezuela.
Caribbean coast of NE Colombia and NW Venezuela.
Known from scattered localities from NC Nicaragua through Costa Rica, Panama, W Colombia, and NW Ecuador.

As currently defined, the species is known from E Panama through NW South America in the E Andean foothills of Colombia and Ecuador, and NW Amazonia in Brazil, Colombia, Venezuela, and Peru (N of the Amazon and W of the Rio Negro).
Found from the right bank of the Tocantins in E Pará S through the Atlantic coast of Brazil to Santa Catarina and inland to the Cerrado, possibly into NE Argentina.
C and S Guyana and N Brazil (SE Roraima, E Amazonas, and N Pará); possibly also found in Suriname.
S and E of the Orinoco in Venezuela, NW Guyana, and N Brazil (N of the Rio Negro and W of the Rio Branco).
SE Brazil, E Paraguay, NE Argentina, and Uruguay.
Found throughout E Bolivia, NW Argentina, W Paraguay, N across C Brazil to Ceará and Pernambuco.
Found from E Peru (Loreto, Ucayali, Cusco, and Madre de Dios) and N Bolivia (Pando) E along the S bank of the Amazon to the left bank of the Tcantins in Brazil.
Known from the E Andes of C Peru (Huánuco, Pasco, Junín, and Cusco).
Known from NE Bolivia (La Paz, Pando), E Peru (Ucayali, Madre de Dios, Cusco), and across S Amazonian Brazil to E Pará (including Marajó Island).
Known ony from two localities in C Peru (Loreto and Pasco). A specimen reported from W Brazil by Bezerra et al. (2019) appears to represent a subadult of M. ronaldi (see Ruelas and Pacheco 2022).
Atlantic Forest of SE Brazil from Espírito Santo to Rio Grande do Sul.

Known as currently defined from scattered localities across E Bolivia (Beni, Santa Cruz, Tarija), N Argentina (Salta), Paraguay (Canendeyú, Presidente Hayes), and Brazil (Distrito Federal, Goiás, Mato Grosso, Mato Grosso del Sur, Minas Gerais, São Paulo, Tocantins).

Reported from C Peru to C Bolivia, although it is unclear if any of these specimens were correctly identified other than genetically confirmed individuals in Bolivia (according to Pavan et al. 2014 and Voss 2022).
N and W of the Orinoco River in Venezuela and probably E Colombia.
Currently known from N Bolivia (La Paz) and E Peru (S of the Amazon).
Found in SE Brazil (Espírito Santo, Rio de Janeiro, Minas Gerais, and São Paulo).
Known only from the type locality in E Venezuela and from nearby Mount Ayangana.
Currently known from the Amazonian lowlands of E Peru (Madre de Dios and Ucayali) and W Brazil (Amazonas) (Brazilian record originally identified as M. handleyi; see Ruelas and Pacheco 2022).
Known from scattered localities S of the Amazon in Brazil (Acre, Rondônia, Mato Grosso, and Pará).
Known only from the type locality in E Bolivia (Santa Cruz); a specimen from Brazil (Mato Grosso) may represent this species, but this remains to be tested.
Atlantic Forest of Brazil from Espírito Santo S to NE Argentina (Misiones).
Currently known from French Guiana and N Brazil (Amapá and E Pará), including Marajó Island; possibly also found in Suriname.
Known from two localities in SE Brazil and NE Argetina (possibly Misiones).
Known from two localities in N Brazil (both in Roraima).
Found in the valley of the Río Balsas of SC Mexico (Guerrero, México, Michoacán, Morelos, Puebla, Jalisco, and Oaxaca).
S Mexico (Chipas and Oaxaca) on the Isthmus of Tehauntepec and Valley of Oaxaca.
Known from SE Mexico (Campeche and Yucatán).
Known only from the Islas Marías (or Tres Marias Islands) off the Pacific coast of Mexico.
The Pacific coast of N Mexico and adjacent inland valleys (Colima, Jalisco, Nayarit, Sinaloa, Durango, Zacatecas).
Known only from the Xingu-Tocantins interfluve of NE Brazil (Pará).

As currently defined, found from S Mexico (S Chiapas) through Central America (confirmed from Guatemala, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panama) and into South America, where found in Colombia, Venezuela, E Ecuador, Peru, N Bolivia, E Paraguay, NE Argentina, and Brazil in Amazonian and the Atlantic Forest; the full distribution of this species has not been fully established.

Restricted to the Guianan Shield (W Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana, NE Brazil), although the species is only currently confirmed from NE Amazonia and whether it occurs throughout the Guianan Shield is uncertain.
Known only from the Chaco of N Argentina (Chaco, Formosa, Misiones).
Found across NE, C, and SE Brazil.
Known from C Brazil to Paraguay and N Argentina; may also occur in Uruguay.
Found across S Brazil and possibly Uruguay.
Found in SE Peru (Madre de Dios), E Bolivia, SW Brazil (Mato Grosso), and W Paraguay.
Known throughout Peru and N Bolivia.
NE and C Brazil (Bahia, Ceará, Goiás, Mato Grosso, Mato Grosso do Sul, Minas Gerais, Pernambuco, Piauí), E Bolivia (Santa Cruz), and E Paraguay (Caazapá, Canindeyú, Cordillera, Paraguarí).
Found at high elevations in the Cordillera de Mérida and Cordillera de Trujillo of W Venezuela and the Cordillera Oriental of Colombia.
Known from widely scattered localities across tropical South America, including Colombia, Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana, Brazil, and Peru.
Currently known from the Andes and N coast of Venezuela and NE and C Colombia.
SE Brazil (Bahia S to Rio Grande do Sul), NE Argentina (Misiones), and possibly Uruguay.
Found in WC Brazil (Mato Grosso, Rondônia), E Bolivia (Santa Cruz), and E Peru (Cusco, Madre de Dios, Pasco, Ucayali).
Found in the Monte Desert and Patagonian Steppe of C and S Argentina (Chubut, La Pampa, Mendoza, Neuquén, Río Negro, and Santa Cruz).
As currently defined, known from E Ecaudor, Peru, and W Bolivia E through the Amazonian lowlands into Brazil and S Colombia as far E as the Rio Branco.
Found in NE Venezuela and Trinidad and Tobago islands.
As currently defined, known from E Panama S along the Andes and adjacent Amazonian lowlands of Colombia, Ecuador, W Brazil, and Peru (S to Madre de Dios), with an isolated record from S Venezuela.
Found in the N portions of the Cordillera Occidental and Cordillera Central of N Colombia (Antioquia, Caldas).
Known only from the E slopes of the Andes in WC Bolivia (La Paz).
Known only from four localities in NW Venezuela.
Only known from the N portion of the Cordillera Central of N Colombia.
The Atlantic Forest of SE Brazil (from Sergipe S to Paraná).
Found throughout Panama, although voucher specimens are not available from W Panama.
Known only fro the E Andean slopes of C Peru (Junín, Pasco).
Found in the valley of the Río Magdalena and in the Cordillera Oriental of Colombia.
S of the Amazon between the Rio Xingu and Rio Madeira in Brazil (Pará, Mato Grosso, Rondônia).
Found in the Andes from W Ecuador through Peru and W Bolivia and the Amazonian lowlands of NW Brazil and S Colombia E to the left bank of the Tapajós.
Known from E Bolivia (Chuquisaca, Santa Cruz) and SW Brazil (Mato Grosso, Mato Grosso del Sur).
Found in the Cordillera de la Costa and Cordillera de Mérida in N and W Venezuela.
Known from only five localities in W Guyana and E Venezuela. Specimens reported from W Brazil are likely don't represent this species (Silva et al. 2017; Voss 2022).
Found in NE Amazonia from N of the lower Amazon and E of the Rio Negro-Orinoco, including Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana, and N Brazil (Amapá, N Pará, NE Amazonas).
Known only from SE Brazil (Rio de Janeiro, Minas Gerais, São Paulo, Paraná).
As currently defined, found in the Guianan Shield (N of the lower Amazon and E of the Rio Negro-Orinoco) in E Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana, and N Brazil (Amapá, Roraima, N Pará).
Found at only three localities in the Yavarí-Ucayali interfluve of NE Peru (Loreto).

As currently defined, found in SE Amazonia (from right bank of the Rio Xingu E along the S bank of the Amazon) and the Atlantic coast to Maranhão and S along the Tocantins and Araguaia rivers (into N Tocantins) of Brazil.
Endemic to C Chile (from Tarapacá S to Maule).
The Cerrado and Caatinga of C and NE Brazil.
Known only from E Paraguay and adjacent Brazil (Mato Grosso do Sul).
Pacific coast of S Peru and N Chile, in the Altiplano of Peru, Bolivia, and Chile, and in the E Andes S to Argentina (Chubut).
As currently defined, found in SE Bolivia, W Paraguay, and N Argentina.
Found along the foothills and E slopes of the Andes in S Bolivia (Tarija) and NW Argentina (Jujuy, Salta, Tucumán, Catamarca).
Known only from W Peru (Ancash, Lima).
Known from few localities in the Cerrado of C and SE Brazil.
The foothills and E slopes of the Andes of N Bolivia (La Paz) to N Argentina (Jujuy, Tucumán).

Known from widely scattered localities across tropical South America, including Amazonia (in Ecuador, Peru, and Brazil) S to E Bolivia (Santa Cruz) and SW Brazil (Mato Grosso), including records in SE Colombia, E Brazil, and French Guiana.
Known from E Peru (Cusco, Junín, Loreto), N Brazil (Amazonas), S Guyana, and French Guiana.
SC Chile and adjacent Argentina between ~35°S to ~39°S.
SC Chile and adjacent Argentina between ~39°S to ~44°S, including Chiloe Island.
Known from the Greaty Sandy, Little Sandy, and N Gibson Deserts of Western Australia and Northern Territory (and possibly the Tanami Desert), W Australia.
Known from the Great Victoria Deserts of Western Australia and South Australia dn the W half of the Simpson Desert of S North Territory and Queensland, W Australia.

Gutiérrez, E. E., & Marinho-Filho, J. (2017). The mammalian faunas endemic to the Cerrado and the Caatinga. ZooKeys, (644), 105.|Teta, P. (2019). The usage of subgenera in mammalian taxonomy. Mammalia, 83(3), 209-211.

mainCommonName: Colombian Western Andes Cloud Forest Mouse
Colombian Central Andes Cloud Forest Mouse
Van Deusen's New Guinea Mountain Rat
Yong Hoi Sen's Woolly Horseshoe Bat

distributionNotes: Vagrants seen aslong USA Atlantic coast as far south as Puerto Rico, more common in New England.
While unusual in the past, large numbers of animals, especially juveniles, found in Gulf of Maine since 1990s. Vagrant sightings and strandings as far south as North Carolina.
Vagrant sightings as far south as New Jersey
Vagrant sightings as far south as New Jersey in Atlantic, Southern California in Pacific
recently re-discovered in Armenia
vagrant sightings in Gulf of Mexico near Texas
occasional strandings in Gulf of Mexico but not live sightings
two stranding records from Florida during the 1980s (Smithsonian strandings database) and one in 2003 (NE Regional Office/NMFS strandings and entanglement database)
Data deficient but thought to be continuous population across Pacific
Found in deeper water in Gulf of Mexico, but very rare strandings
Mostly found in deeper water but one of most common species stranded in Western North Atlantic, present year-round off of Cape Hatteras, NC,USA. Have been found as far north as Cape Cod, MA, USA.
Range primarily known from stranding data
Wide distribution, but mostly in deeper oceanic waters, generally rare sightings and strandings. May be resident population off of NC.
